  "article_text": [
    "the goal of this paper is to establish ( graded ) affine cellularity in the sense of koenig and xi @xcite for the khovanov - lauda - rouquier algebras @xmath0 of finite lie type .",
    "in fact , we construct a chain of affine cell ideals in @xmath0 which are generated by idempotents .",
    "this stronger property is analogous to quasi - heredity for finite dimensional algebras , and by a general result of koenig and xi ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 4.4 ) , it also implies finiteness of the global dimension of @xmath0 .",
    "thus we obtain a new proof of ( a slightly stronger version of ) a recent result of kato @xcite and mcnamara @xcite ( see also @xcite ) . as another application",
    ", one gets a theory of standard and proper standard modules , cf .",
    "it would be interesting to apply this paper to prove the conjectural ( graded ) cellularity of cyclotomic klr algebras of finite types .",
    "our approach is independent of the homological results in @xcite , @xcite and @xcite ( which relies on @xcite ) .",
    "the connection between the theory developed in @xcite and this paper is explained in @xcite .",
    "this paper generalizes @xcite , where analogous results were obtained for finite type @xmath1 .",
    "we now give a definition of ( graded ) affine cellular algebra from ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition 2.1 ) . throughout the paper , unless otherwise stated , we assume that all algebras are ( @xmath2)-graded , all ideals , subspaces , etc .",
    "are homogeneous , and all homomorphisms are homogeneous degree zero homomorphisms with respect to the given gradings . for this introduction",
    ", we fix a noetherian domain @xmath3 ( later on it will be sufficient to work with @xmath4 ) .",
    "let @xmath1 be a ( graded ) unital @xmath3-algebra with a @xmath3-anti - involution @xmath5 .",
    "a ( two - sided ) ideal @xmath6 in @xmath1 is called an _ affine cell ideal _ if the following conditions are satisfied :    1 .",
    "@xmath7 ; 2 .",
    "there exists an affine @xmath3-algebra @xmath8 with a @xmath3-involution @xmath9 and a free @xmath3-module @xmath10 of finite rank such that @xmath11 has an @xmath1-@xmath8-bimodule structure , with the right @xmath8-module structure induced by the regular right @xmath8-module structure on @xmath8 ; 3 .",
    "let @xmath12 be the @xmath8-@xmath1-bimodule with left @xmath8-module structure induced by the regular left @xmath8-module structure on @xmath8 and right @xmath1-module structure defined by @xmath13 where @xmath14 ; then there is an @xmath1-@xmath1-bimodule isomorphism @xmath15 , such that the following diagram commutes : + @xmath16   \\ar^{\\tau}[d ] & & \\delta \\otimes_b\\delta ' \\ar^{v \\otimes b \\otimes b ' \\otimes w \\mapsto w \\otimes \\si(b ' ) \\otimes \\si(b ) \\otimes v } [ d ] \\\\",

    "we introduce some notation referring the reader to the main body of the paper for details .",
    "fix a cartan datum of finite type , and denote by @xmath24 the set of positive roots , and by @xmath25 the positive part of the root lattice .",
    "for @xmath26 we have the klr algebra @xmath0 with standard idempotents @xmath27 .",

    "this is partially ordered with respect to a certain bilexicographic order ` @xmath30 ' .",
    "to any @xmath31 one associates a proper standard module @xmath32 and a word @xmath33 .",

    "the map @xmath51 is an isomorphism of graded algebras ; 4 .",

    "multiplication provides an isomorphism @xmath57 7 .",
    "@xmath58 .",
    "main theorem(vii ) shows that each affine cell ideal @xmath59 in @xmath60 is generated by an idempotent .",
    "this , together with the fact that each algebra @xmath61 is a polynomial algebra , is enough to invoke ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 4.4 ) to get    * corollary . *",
    "_ if the ground ring @xmath3 has finite global dimension , then the algebra @xmath0 has finite global dimension . _",
    "this seems to be a slight generalization of @xcite,@xcite,@xcite in two ways : @xcite assumes that @xmath3 is a field of characteristic zero ( and the lie type is simply - laced ) , while @xcite,@xcite assume that @xmath3 is a field ; moreover , @xcite,@xcite,@xcite deal with categories of graded modules only , while our corollary holds for the algebra @xmath0 even as an ungraded algebra .",
    "the paper is organized as follows .",
    "section 2 contains preliminaries needed for the rest of the paper .",
    "the first subsection contains mostly general conventions that will be used .",
    "subsection  [ slie ] goes over the lie theoretic notation that we employ .",
    "we move on in subsection  [ ssklr ] to the definition and basic results of khovanov - lauda - rouquier ( klr ) algebras .",
    "the next two subsections are devoted to recalling results about the representation theory of klr algebras .",
    "then , in subsection  [ ssqg ] , we introduce our notation regarding quantum groups , and recall some well - known basis theorems .",
    "the next subsection is devoted to the connection between klr algebras and quantum groups , namely the categorification theorems .",
    "finally , subsection  [ ssdf ] contains an easy direct proof of a graded dimension formula for the klr algebras , cf .",
    "* corollary 3.15 ) .",
    "section 3 is devoted to constructing a basis for the klr algebras that is amenable to checking affine cellularity .",
    "we begin in subsection  [ sssswid ] by choosing some special weight idempotents and proving some properties they enjoy .",
    "subsection  [ snota ] introduces the notation that allows us to define our affine cellular structure .",
    "this subsection also contains the crucial hypothesis  [ hprop ] .",
    "next , in subsection  [ sspower ] , we come up with an affine cellular basis in the special case corresponding to a root partition of that is a power of a single root .",
    "finally , we use this in the last subsection to come up with our affine cellular basis in full generality .    in section 4",
    "we show how the affine cellular basis is used to prove that the klr algebras are affine cellular .    finally , in section 5",
    "we verify hypothesis  [ hprop ] for all positive roots in all finite types .",
    "we begin in subsection  [ sshomog ] by recalling some results concerning homogeneous representations . in subsection  [ ssslo ]",
    "we recall the definition of special lyndon orders and lyndon words , which will serve as the special weights of subsection  [ sssswid ] .",
    "the next subsection is devoted to verifying hypothesis  [ hprop ] in the special case when the cuspidal representation corresponding to the positive root is homogeneous .",
    "we then employ this in subsection  [ ssade ] to show that the hypothesis holds in simply - laced types .",
    "finally , we have subsection  [ ssbcfg ] , wherein we verify the hypothesis by hand in the non - symmetric types .",
    "in this section we set up the theory of klr algebras and their connection to quantum groups following mainly @xcite and also @xcite .",
    "only subsection  [ ssdf ] contains some new material .      throughout the paper we work over the ground ring @xmath62 which is assumed to be either @xmath2 or an arbitrary field @xmath63 .",

    "we use the results of the previous subsections to obtain affine cellular bases of the klr algebras of finite type .",
    "fix @xmath26 and @xmath588 .",
    "define @xmath45 , and write @xmath775 for the image of an element @xmath776 .",
    "we begin with some easy consequences of the previous section .",
    "[ csymmgen ] we have    1 .   given @xmath777 , @xmath744 commutes with @xmath778 , @xmath49 , and @xmath779 .",
    "2 .   up to a grading shift , @xmath780 .",
    "the map @xmath781 sending @xmath782 to right multiplication by @xmath783 is an isomorphism of algebras .",
    "the map @xmath784 sending @xmath782 to left multiplication by @xmath783 is an isomorphism of algebras .",
    "claim ( i ) follows directly from corollary  [ csymm ] and the definitions .",
    "the proof of claim ( ii ) is similar to that of lemma  [ linduct ] . to be precise ,",
    "by corollary  [ lparaideal2 ] we have a map @xmath785 which by frobenius reciprocity determines a homomorphism @xmath786    we now claim that @xmath787 .",
    "it is enough to prove that @xmath788 for all @xmath467 . by exactness of induction",
    ", it follows that @xmath789 has an exhaustive filtration by @xmath790 . by theorem  [ tstand ] , @xmath791 , which proves the claim .    since @xmath792 we obtain a map @xmath793 the homomorphisms @xmath675 map the evident cyclic generators to each other , and so are inverse isomorphisms .",

    "recall the theory of standard modules reviewed in  [ sssmt ] .",
    "we now specialize to the case of a _ lyndon _ convex order on @xmath112 as studied in @xcite . for this",
    "we first need to fix a total order ` @xmath30 ' on @xmath94 .",
    "this gives rise to a lexicographic order ` @xmath30 ' on the set @xmath125 .",
    "in particular , each finite dimensional @xmath0-module has its ( lexicographically ) highest word , and the highest word of an irreducible module determines the irreducible module uniquely up to an isomorphism .",
    "this leads to the natural notion of _ dominant words _ ( called good words in @xcite ) , namely the elements of @xmath861 which occur as highest words of finite dimensional @xmath0-modules .",
    "the dominant words of cuspidal modules are characterized among all dominant words by the property that they are _ lyndon words _ , so we refer to them as _",
    "dominant lyndon words_. there is an explicit bijection @xmath892 uniquely determined by the property @xmath893 .",
    "note that this notation @xmath449 will be consistent with the same notation used in  [ sssswid ]",
    ".    setting @xmath894 if and only if @xmath895 for @xmath896 defines a total order on @xmath112 called a _ lyndon order_. it is known that each lyndon order is convex , and the theory of standard modules for lyndon orders , developed in @xcite , fits into the general theory described in  [ sssmt ] .",
    "however , working with lyndon orders allows us to be a little more explicit .",
    "in particular , given a a root partition @xmath259 , set @xmath897      from now on , we fix the notation for the dynkin diagrams as follows : @xmath899{$a_\\ell\\quad(\\ell \\geq 1)$ } ;    \\draw ( 0,0)node[above]{$1 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw   ( 0.15,0)--(0.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 1,0)node[above]{$2 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw [   dotted ] ( 1.15,0)--(2.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 3,0)node[above]{$\\ell-1 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw   ( 3.15,0)--(3.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 4,0)node[above]{$\\ell$ } circle ( 0.10 ) ; \\end{dynkin}\\quad \\begin{dynkin }    \\draw ( .5,.8)node[anchor = west , font=\\normalsize]{$b_\\ell\\quad(\\ell \\geq 2)$ } ;    \\draw ( 0,0)node[above]{$1 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw   ( 0.15,0)--(0.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 1,0)node[above]{$2 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw [   dotted ] ( 1.15,0)--(2.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 3,0)node[above]{$\\ell-1 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw ( 3.15,.05)--(3.85,.05 ) ;    \\draw ( 3.15,-.05)--(3.85,-.05 ) ;    \\draw ( 3.5,0)node{$>$ } ;    \\draw ( 4,0)node[above]{$\\ell$ } circle ( 0.10 ) ; \\end{dynkin}\\quad \\begin{dynkin }    \\draw ( .5,.8)node[anchor = west , font=\\normalsize]{$c_\\ell\\quad(\\ell \\geq 3)$ } ;    \\draw ( 0,0)node[above]{$1 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw   ( 0.15,0)--(0.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 1,0)node[above]{$2 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw [   dotted ] ( 1.15,0)--(2.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 3,0)node[above]{$\\ell-1 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw ( 3.15,.05)--(3.85,.05 ) ;    \\draw ( 3.15,-.05)--(3.85,-.05 ) ;    \\draw ( 3.5,0)node{$<$ } ;    \\draw ( 4,0)node[above]{$\\ell$ } circle ( 0.10 ) ; \\end{dynkin}\\ ] ] @xmath899{$d_\\ell\\quad(\\ell \\geq 4)$ } ;    \\draw ( 0,0)node[above]{$1 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw   ( 0.15,0)--(0.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 1,0)node[above]{$2 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw [   dotted ] ( 1.15,0)--(2.85,0 ) ;    \\draw ( 3,0)node[above]{$\\ell-2 $ } circle ( 0.10 ) ;    \\draw",

    "since @xmath1199 , we have that @xmath659 is generated by @xmath1200^{{\\mathfrak{s}}_3 } \\bar e_\\be$ ] .",

    "this is clearly true unless @xmath165 is one of the twelve permutations that stabilizes the weight @xmath449 .",
    "of these , six produce a negative degree . since @xmath565 spans the smallest degree component of @xmath1037 we the claim holds for these six permutations .",
    "two of the remaining six permutations end with the cycle @xmath1211 .",
    "since @xmath1212 , this implies that the claim holds for them too .",
    "finally , reduced decompositions for the remaining non - identity permutations may be chosen so that @xmath1213 by lemmas  [ lbadwordsnew ] and [ lhighestwt ] .",

    "m. khovanov and a. lauda , a diagrammatic approach to categorification of quantum groups i , _ represent .",
    "* 13 * ( 2009 ) , 309347 .",
    "m. khovanov and a. lauda , a diagrammatic approach to categorification of quantum groups ii , _ trans .",

    "z. _ , to appear ; arxiv:1210.6556 .",
    "a. kleshchev and a. ram , representations of khovanov - lauda - rouquier algebras and combinatorics of lyndon words , _ math .",
    "* 349 * ( 2011 ) , no .",
    "4 , 943975 . a. kleshchev and a. ram , homogeneous representations of khovanovlauda algebras , _ j. eur . math . soc . _",

    "b. leclerc , dual canonical bases , quantum shuffles and @xmath69-characters , _ math .",
    "z. _ * 246 * ( 2004 ) , 691732 .",
    "g. lusztig , _ introduction to quantum groups _ ,",
    "progress in mathematics 110 , birkhuser , boston , 1993 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we prove that the khovanov - lauda - rouquier algebras @xmath0 of finite type are ( graded ) affine cellular in the sense of koenig and xi . </S>",
    "<S> in fact , we establish a stronger property , namely that the affine cell ideals in @xmath0 are generated by idempotents . </S>",
    "<S> this in particular implies the ( known ) result that the global dimension of @xmath0 is finite . </S>"
  ]
}
